sn35.159:0.3.eng: Focus, the Exterior, and the End of Relishing

sn35.159:1.1.pli: “Rūpe, bhikkhave, yoniso manasi karotha, rūpāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassatha.
sn35.159:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, rationally apply the mind to sights. Truly see the impermanence of sights.

sn35.159:1.2.pli: Rūpe, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yoniso manasikaronto, rūpāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassanto rūpesupi nibbindati.
sn35.159:1.2.eng: When a mendicant does this, they grow disillusioned with sights.

sn35.159:1.3.eng: When relishing ends, greed ends. When greed ends, relishing ends.

sn35.159:1.5.eng: When relishing and greed end, the mind is said to be well freed.

sn35.159:1.6.eng: Rationally apply the mind to sounds …

sn35.159:1.10.pli: dhamme, bhikkhave, yoniso manasi karotha, dhammāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassatha.
sn35.159:1.10.eng: ideas. Truly see the impermanence of ideas.

sn35.159:1.11.pli: Dhamme, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yoniso manasikaronto, dhammāniccatañca yathābhūtaṃ samanupassanto dhammesupi nibbindati.
sn35.159:1.11.eng: When a mendicant does this, they grow disillusioned with ideas.

sn35.159:1.14.eng: When relishing and greed end, the mind is said to be well freed.”

sn35.16:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I went in search of the gratification of sights,

sn35.16:1.3.pli: Yāvatā rūpānaṃ assādo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.

sn35.16:1.6.pli: Yāvatā rūpānaṃ ādīnavo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.

sn35.16:1.9.pli: Yāvatā rūpānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ, paññāya me taṃ sudiṭṭhaṃ.

sn35.16:1.16.pli: Yāvatā dhammānaṃ assādo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.

sn35.16:1.19.pli: Yāvatā dhammānaṃ ādīnavo paññāya me so sudiṭṭho.

sn35.16:1.22.pli: Yāvatā dhammānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ, paññāya me taṃ sudiṭṭhaṃ.

sn35.16:2.1.pli: Yāvakīvañcāhaṃ, bhikkhave, imesaṃ channaṃ bāhirānaṃ āyatanānaṃ assādañca assādato, ādīnavañca ādīnavato, nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ nābbhaññāsiṃ …pe… paccaññāsiṃ.

sn35.16:2.3.pli: ‘akuppā me vimutti, ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo’”ti.

sn35.160:0.3.eng: On Immersion at Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

sn35.160:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati jīvakambavane.
sn35.160:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in Jīvaka’s Mango Grove.
sn35.160:1.1.comm: This monastery belonged to the Buddha’s doctor, Jīvaka, who appears in DN 2. His story is told in Kd 8, where we learn that he was raised by Prince Abhaya of Magadha, a Jain (MN 58) who was also interested in the teachings of Pūraṇa Kassapa (SN 46.56). MN 55 on eating meat is addressed to him. | This discourse and the next are similar to SN 22.5–6.

sn35.160:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn35.160:1.5.eng: For a mendicant with immersion, things become truly clear.

sn35.160:1.7.pli: Cakkhuṃ aniccanti yathābhūtaṃ okkhāyati, rūpā aniccāti yathābhūtaṃ okkhāyati, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ aniccanti yathābhūtaṃ okkhāyati, cakkhusamphasso aniccoti yathābhūtaṃ okkhāyati, yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccanti yathābhūtaṃ okkhāyati …pe…
sn35.160:1.7.eng: It becomes truly clear that the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are impermanent. And it also becomes truly clear that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is impermanent.

sn35.160:1.8.eng: It becomes truly clear that the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.160:1.9.pli: mano aniccoti yathābhūtaṃ okkhāyati, dhammā aniccāti yathābhūtaṃ okkhāyati …pe…
sn35.160:1.9.eng: mind, ideas, mind consciousness, and mind contact are impermanent.

sn35.160:1.10.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccanti yathābhūtaṃ okkhāyati.
sn35.160:1.10.eng: And it also becomes truly clear that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is impermanent.

sn35.160:1.12.eng: For a mendicant with immersion, things become truly clear.”

sn35.161:0.3.eng: On Retreat at Jīvaka’s Mango Grove

sn35.161:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati jīvakambavane.
sn35.161:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in Jīvaka’s Mango Grove.

sn35.161:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

sn35.161:1.4.eng: For a mendicant who meditates in retreat, things become truly clear.

sn35.161:1.6.pli: Cakkhuṃ aniccanti yathābhūtaṃ okkhāyati, rūpā aniccāti yathābhūtaṃ okkhāyati, cakkhuviññāṇaṃ aniccanti yathābhūtaṃ okkhāyati, cakkhusamphasso aniccoti yathābhūtaṃ okkhāyati, yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccanti yathābhūtaṃ okkhāyati …pe…
sn35.161:1.6.eng: It becomes truly clear that the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact are impermanent. And it also becomes truly clear that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is impermanent. …

sn35.161:1.7.eng: It becomes truly clear that the mind, ideas, mind consciousness, and mind contact are impermanent.

sn35.161:1.10.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccanti yathābhūtaṃ okkhāyati.
sn35.161:1.10.eng: And it also becomes truly clear that the painful, pleasant, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is impermanent.

sn35.161:1.12.eng: For a mendicant who meditates in retreat, things become truly clear.”

sn35.162:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā koṭṭhiko bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.162:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita went up to the Buddha … and asked him,
sn35.162:1.1.comm: For Mahākoṭṭhita, see note on SN 22.122:1.1. | This discourse parallels SN 22.137.

sn35.162:1.2.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn35.162:1.2.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn35.162:2.1.pli: “Yaṃ kho, koṭṭhika, aniccaṃ tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.162:2.1.eng: “Koṭṭhita, you should give up desire for what is impermanent.

sn35.162:2.3.pli: Cakkhu kho, koṭṭhika, aniccaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.162:2.4.pli: Rūpā aniccā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.162:2.5.pli: Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.162:2.6.pli: Cakkhusamphasso anicco; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.162:2.6.eng: and eye contact are impermanent: you should give up desire for them.

sn35.162:2.7.pli: Yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo …pe…
sn35.162:2.7.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is also impermanent: you should give up desire for it.

sn35.162:2.8.pli: jivhā aniccā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.162:2.9.pli: Rasā aniccā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.162:2.10.pli: Jivhāviññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.162:2.11.pli: Jivhāsamphasso anicco; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.162:2.12.pli: Yampidaṃ jivhāsamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo …pe…

sn35.162:2.13.pli: mano anicco; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.162:2.14.pli: Dhammā aniccā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.162:2.15.pli: Manoviññāṇaṃ aniccaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.162:2.16.pli: Manosamphasso anicco; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.162:2.16.eng: and mind contact are impermanent: you should give up desire for them.

sn35.162:2.17.pli: Yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.162:2.17.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is also impermanent: you should give up desire for it.

sn35.162:2.18.pli: Yaṃ kho, koṭṭhika, aniccaṃ tatra te chando pahātabbo”ti.
sn35.162:2.18.eng: Koṭṭhita, you should give up desire for what is impermanent.”

sn35.163:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko …pe… bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.163:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita … said to the Buddha:

sn35.163:1.2.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn35.163:1.3.pli: “Yaṃ kho, koṭṭhika, dukkhaṃ tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.163:1.3.eng: “Koṭṭhita, you should give up desire for what is suffering.

sn35.163:1.5.pli: Cakkhu kho, koṭṭhika, dukkhaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.163:1.6.pli: Rūpā dukkhā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.163:1.7.pli: Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ dukkhaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.163:1.8.pli: Cakkhusamphasso dukkho; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.163:1.8.eng: and eye contact are suffering: you should give up desire for them.

sn35.163:1.9.pli: Yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi dukkhaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo …pe…
sn35.163:1.9.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is also suffering; you should give up desire for it.

sn35.163:1.10.pli: jivhā dukkhā; tatra te chando pahātabbo …pe…

sn35.163:1.11.pli: mano dukkho; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.163:1.12.pli: Dhammā dukkhā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.163:1.13.pli: Manoviññāṇaṃ dukkhaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.163:1.14.pli: Manosamphasso dukkho; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.163:1.14.eng: and mind contact are suffering: you should give up desire for them.

sn35.163:1.15.pli: Yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi dukkhaṃ; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.163:1.15.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is also suffering: you should give up desire for it.

sn35.163:1.16.pli: Yaṃ kho, koṭṭhika, dukkhaṃ tatra te chando pahātabbo”ti.
sn35.163:1.16.eng: Koṭṭhita, you should give up desire for what is suffering.”

sn35.164:1.3.pli: “Yo kho, koṭṭhika, anattā tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.164:1.3.eng: “Koṭṭhita, you should give up desire for what is not-self.

sn35.164:1.5.pli: Cakkhu kho, koṭṭhika, anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.164:1.6.pli: Rūpā anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.164:1.7.pli: Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.164:1.8.pli: Cakkhusamphasso anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.164:1.8.eng: and eye contact are not-self: you should give up desire for them.

sn35.164:1.9.pli: Yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo …pe…
sn35.164:1.9.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on eye contact is also not-self: You should give up desire for it.

sn35.164:1.10.pli: jivhā anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo …pe…

sn35.164:1.11.pli: mano anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.164:1.12.pli: Dhammā anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.

sn35.164:1.15.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi anattā; tatra te chando pahātabbo.
sn35.164:1.15.eng: The pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact is also not-self: you should give up desire for it.

sn35.164:1.16.pli: Yo kho, koṭṭhika, anattā, tatra te chando pahātabbo”ti.
sn35.164:1.16.eng: Koṭṭhita, you should give up desire for what is not-self.”

sn35.165:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe…
sn35.165:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha …

sn35.165:1.2.pli: ekamantaṃ nisinno so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

sn35.165:1.3.pli: “kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato kathaṃ passato micchādiṭṭhi pahīyatī”ti?
sn35.165:1.3.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that wrong view is given up?”

sn35.165:2.1.pli: “Cakkhuṃ kho, bhikkhu, aniccato jānato passato micchādiṭṭhi pahīyati.
sn35.165:2.1.eng: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as impermanent, wrong view is given up. …

sn35.165:2.2.pli: Rūpe aniccato jānato passato micchādiṭṭhi pahīyati.

sn35.165:2.3.pli: Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ aniccato jānato passato micchādiṭṭhi pahīyati.

sn35.165:2.4.pli: Cakkhusamphassaṃ aniccato jānato passato micchādiṭṭhi pahīyati …pe…

sn35.165:2.5.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi aniccato jānato passato micchādiṭṭhi pahīyati.
sn35.165:2.5.eng: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact as impermanent, wrong view is given up.

sn35.165:2.6.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, jānato evaṃ passato micchādiṭṭhi pahīyatī”ti.
sn35.165:2.6.eng: This is how to know and see so that wrong view is given up.”

sn35.166:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha …

sn35.166:1.3.pli: “kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato kathaṃ passato sakkāyadiṭṭhi pahīyatī”ti?
sn35.166:1.3.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that substantialist view is given up?”

sn35.166:1.4.pli: “Cakkhuṃ kho, bhikkhu, dukkhato jānato passato sakkāyadiṭṭhi pahīyati.
sn35.166:1.4.eng: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as suffering, substantialist view is given up. …

sn35.166:1.5.pli: Rūpe dukkhato jānato passato sakkāyadiṭṭhi pahīyati.

sn35.166:1.6.pli: Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ dukkhato jānato passato sakkāyadiṭṭhi pahīyati.

sn35.166:1.7.pli: Cakkhusamphassaṃ dukkhato jānato passato sakkāyadiṭṭhi pahīyati …pe…

sn35.166:1.8.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi dukkhato jānato passato sakkāyadiṭṭhi pahīyati.
sn35.166:1.8.eng: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises dependent on mind contact as suffering, substantialist view is given up.

sn35.166:1.9.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhu, jānato evaṃ passato sakkāyadiṭṭhi pahīyatī”ti.
sn35.166:1.9.eng: This is how to know and see so that substantialist view is given up.”

sn35.167:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha …

sn35.167:1.3.pli: “kathaṃ nu kho, bhante, jānato kathaṃ passato attānudiṭṭhi pahīyatī”ti?
sn35.167:1.3.eng: “Sir, how does one know and see so that theory of self is given up?”

sn35.167:1.4.pli: “Cakkhuṃ kho, bhikkhu, anattato jānato passato attānudiṭṭhi pahīyati.
sn35.167:1.4.eng: “Mendicant, knowing and seeing the eye, sights, eye consciousness, and eye contact as not-self, theory of self is given up. …

sn35.167:1.5.pli: Rūpe anattato jānato passato attānudiṭṭhi pahīyati.

sn35.167:1.6.pli: Cakkhuviññāṇaṃ anattato jānato passato attānudiṭṭhi pahīyati.

sn35.167:1.7.pli: Cakkhusamphassaṃ anattato jānato passato attānudiṭṭhi pahīyati.

sn35.167:1.8.pli: Yampidaṃ cakkhusamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi anattato jānato passato attānudiṭṭhi pahīyati …pe…

sn35.167:1.9.pli: jivhaṃ anattato jānato passato attānudiṭṭhi pahīyati …pe…

sn35.167:1.10.pli: manaṃ anattato jānato passato attānudiṭṭhi pahīyati.

sn35.167:1.14.pli: yampidaṃ manosamphassapaccayā uppajjati vedayitaṃ sukhaṃ vā dukkhaṃ vā adukkhamasukhaṃ vā tampi anattato jānato passato attānudiṭṭhi pahīyatī”ti.
sn35.167:1.14.eng: And also knowing and seeing the pleasant, painful, or neutral feeling that arises conditioned by mind contact as not-self, theory of self is given up.”

sn35.168:1.1.pli: “Yaṃ, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ, tatra vo chando pahātabbo.
sn35.168:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should give up desire for what is impermanent.
sn35.168:1.1.comm: This chapter is titled saṭṭhipeyyālavagga, “The Chapter of Sixty Abbreviated Texts”. I follow MS, BJT, and Bodhi, which give the full count of sixty. The PTS edition, by combining each triad of discourses as one, numbers only 19 discourses up to 186. Its numbering remains out of sync for the remainder of this Saṁyutta.

sn35.168:1.3.pli: Cakkhu, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ; tatra vo chando pahātabbo …pe…
sn35.168:1.3.eng: The eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind are impermanent:

sn35.168:1.4.pli: jivhā aniccā; tatra vo chando pahātabbo …pe…

sn35.168:1.5.pli: mano anicco; tatra vo chando pahātabbo.
sn35.168:1.5.eng: you should give up desire for them.

sn35.168:1.6.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ, tatra vo chando pahātabbo”ti.
sn35.168:1.6.eng: You should give up desire for what is impermanent.”

sn35.169:1.1.pli: “Yaṃ, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ, tatra vo rāgo pahātabbo.
sn35.169:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should give up greed for what is impermanent.

sn35.169:1.3.eng: The eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind are impermanent …”

sn35.169:1.9.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ, tatra vo rāgo pahātabbo”ti.

sn35.17:1.1.pli: “No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, cakkhussa assādo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā cakkhusmiṃ sārajjeyyuṃ.
sn35.17:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, if there were no gratification in the eye, sentient beings wouldn’t be aroused by it.

sn35.17:1.2.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi cakkhussa assādo tasmā sattā cakkhusmiṃ sārajjanti.
sn35.17:1.2.eng: But since there is gratification in the eye, sentient beings are aroused by it.

sn35.17:1.3.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, cakkhussa ādīnavo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā cakkhusmiṃ nibbindeyyuṃ.
sn35.17:1.3.eng: If the eye had no drawback, sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.

sn35.17:1.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi cakkhussa ādīnavo tasmā sattā cakkhusmiṃ nibbindanti.
sn35.17:1.4.eng: But since the eye has a drawback, sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.

sn35.17:1.5.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, cakkhussa nissaraṇaṃ abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā cakkhusmā nissareyyuṃ.
sn35.17:1.5.eng: If there were no escape from the eye, sentient beings wouldn’t escape from it.

sn35.17:1.6.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi cakkhussa nissaraṇaṃ tasmā sattā cakkhusmā nissaranti.
sn35.17:1.6.eng: But since there is an escape from the eye, sentient beings do escape from it.

sn35.17:1.7.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, sotassa assādo abhavissa …
sn35.17:1.7.eng: If there were no gratification in the ear …

sn35.17:1.8.pli: no cedaṃ, bhikkhave, ghānassa assādo abhavissa …

sn35.17:1.9.pli: no cedaṃ, bhikkhave, jivhāya assādo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā jivhāya sārajjeyyuṃ.

sn35.17:1.10.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi jivhāya assādo, tasmā sattā jivhāya sārajjanti.

sn35.17:1.11.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, jivhāya ādīnavo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā jivhāya nibbindeyyuṃ.

sn35.17:1.12.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi jivhāya ādīnavo, tasmā sattā jivhāya nibbindanti.

sn35.17:1.13.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, jivhāya nissaraṇaṃ abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā jivhāya nissareyyuṃ.

sn35.17:1.14.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi jivhāya nissaraṇaṃ, tasmā sattā jivhāya nissaranti.

sn35.17:1.15.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, kāyassa assādo abhavissa …

sn35.17:1.16.pli: no cedaṃ, bhikkhave, manassa assādo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā manasmiṃ sārajjeyyuṃ.
sn35.17:1.16.eng: mind, sentient beings wouldn’t be aroused by it.

sn35.17:1.17.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi manassa assādo, tasmā sattā manasmiṃ sārajjanti.
sn35.17:1.17.eng: But since there is gratification in the mind, sentient beings are aroused by it.

sn35.17:1.18.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, manassa ādīnavo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā manasmiṃ nibbindeyyuṃ.
sn35.17:1.18.eng: If the mind had no drawback, sentient beings wouldn’t grow disillusioned with it.

sn35.17:1.19.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi manassa ādīnavo, tasmā sattā manasmiṃ nibbindanti.
sn35.17:1.19.eng: But since the mind has a drawback, sentient beings do grow disillusioned with it.

sn35.17:1.20.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, manassa nissaraṇaṃ abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā manasmā nissareyyuṃ.
sn35.17:1.20.eng: If there were no escape from the mind, sentient beings wouldn’t escape from it.

sn35.17:1.21.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi manassa nissaraṇaṃ, tasmā sattā manasmā nissaranti.
sn35.17:1.21.eng: But since there is an escape from the mind, sentient beings do escape from it.

sn35.17:2.1.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, sattā imesaṃ channaṃ ajjhattikānaṃ āyatanānaṃ assādañca assādato, ādīnavañca ādīnavato, nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ nābbhaññaṃsu, neva tāva, bhikkhave, sattā sadevakā lokā samārakā sabrahmakā sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya nissaṭā visaññuttā vippamuttā vimariyādīkatena cetasā vihariṃsu.
sn35.17:2.1.eng: As long as sentient beings don’t truly understand these six interior sense fields’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, they haven’t escaped from this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—and they don’t live detached, liberated, with mind free of boundaries.

sn35.17:2.2.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, sattā imesaṃ channaṃ ajjhattikānaṃ āyatanānaṃ assādañca assādato, ādīnavañca ādīnavato, nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññaṃsu, atha, bhikkhave, sattā sadevakā lokā samārakā sabrahmakā sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya nissaṭā visaññuttā vippamuttā vimariyādīkatena cetasā viharantī”ti.
sn35.17:2.2.eng: But when sentient beings truly understand these six interior sense fields’ gratification, drawback, and escape for what they are, they’ve escaped from this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—and they live detached, liberated, with mind free of boundaries.”

sn35.170:0.3.eng: Desire and Greed for the Impermanent Interior

sn35.170:1.1.pli: “Yaṃ, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ, tatra vo chandarāgo pahātabbo.
sn35.170:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should give up desire and greed for what is impermanent.

sn35.170:1.3.eng: The eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind are impermanent …”

sn35.170:1.9.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ, tatra vo chandarāgo pahātabbo”ti.

sn35.171-173:0.3.eng: Desire, Etc. for the Suffering Interior

sn35.171-173:1.1.pli: “Yaṃ, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ, tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo.
sn35.171-173:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should give up desire … greed … desire and greed for what is suffering.

sn35.171-173:1.3.pli: Cakkhu, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ; tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo …pe…

sn35.171-173:1.5.pli: mano dukkho; tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo.

sn35.171-173:1.6.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo”ti.

sn35.174-176:0.3.eng: Desire, Etc. for the Not-Self Interior

sn35.174-176:1.1.pli: “Yo, bhikkhave, anattā, tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo.
sn35.174-176:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should give up desire … greed … desire and greed for what is not-self.

sn35.174-176:1.3.pli: Cakkhu, bhikkhave, anattā; tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo …pe…
sn35.174-176:1.3.eng: The eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind are not-self …”

sn35.174-176:1.4.pli: jivhā anattā; tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo …pe…

sn35.174-176:1.5.pli: mano anattā; tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo.

sn35.174-176:1.6.pli: Yo, bhikkhave, anattā tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo”ti.

sn35.177-179:0.3.eng: Desire, Etc. for the Impermanent Exterior

sn35.177-179:1.1.pli: “Yaṃ, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ, tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo.
sn35.177-179:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should give up desire … greed … desire and greed for what is impermanent.

sn35.177-179:1.3.pli: Rūpā, bhikkhave, aniccā; tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo.

sn35.177-179:1.4.pli: Saddā aniccā; tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo.

sn35.177-179:1.5.pli: Gandhā aniccā; tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo.

sn35.177-179:1.6.pli: Rasā aniccā; tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo.

sn35.177-179:1.7.pli: Phoṭṭhabbā aniccā; tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo.

sn35.177-179:1.8.pli: Dhammā aniccā; tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo.

sn35.177-179:1.9.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, aniccaṃ tatra vo chando pahātabbo, rāgo pahātabbo, chandarāgo pahātabbo”ti.

sn35.18:1.1.pli: “No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpānaṃ assādo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā rūpesu sārajjeyyuṃ.
sn35.18:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, if there were no gratification in sights, sentient beings wouldn’t be aroused by them. …”

sn35.18:1.2.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi rūpānaṃ assādo, tasmā sattā rūpesu sārajjanti.

sn35.18:1.3.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpānaṃ ādīnavo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā rūpesu nibbindeyyuṃ.

sn35.18:1.4.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi rūpānaṃ ādīnavo, tasmā sattā rūpesu nibbindanti.

sn35.18:1.5.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, rūpānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā rūpehi nissareyyuṃ.

sn35.18:1.6.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi rūpānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ, tasmā sattā rūpehi nissaranti.

sn35.18:1.11.pli: dhammānaṃ assādo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā dhammesu sārajjeyyuṃ.

sn35.18:1.12.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi dhammānaṃ assādo, tasmā sattā dhammesu sārajjanti.

sn35.18:1.13.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṃ ādīnavo abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā dhammesu nibbindeyyuṃ.

sn35.18:1.14.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi dhammānaṃ ādīnavo, tasmā sattā dhammesu nibbindanti.

sn35.18:1.15.pli: No cedaṃ, bhikkhave, dhammānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ abhavissa, nayidaṃ sattā dhammehi nissareyyuṃ.

sn35.18:1.16.pli: Yasmā ca kho, bhikkhave, atthi dhammānaṃ nissaraṇaṃ, tasmā sattā dhammehi nissaranti.

sn35.18:2.1.pli: Yāvakīvañca, bhikkhave, sattā imesaṃ channaṃ bāhirānaṃ āyatanānaṃ assādañca assādato, ādīnavañca ādīnavato, nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ nābbhaññaṃsu, neva tāva, bhikkhave, sattā sadevakā lokā samārakā sabrahmakā sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya nissaṭā visaññuttā vippamuttā vimariyādīkatena cetasā vihariṃsu.

sn35.18:2.2.pli: Yato ca kho, bhikkhave, sattā imesaṃ channaṃ bāhirānaṃ āyatanānaṃ assādañca assādato, ādīnavañca ādīnavato, nissaraṇañca nissaraṇato yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññaṃsu, atha, bhikkhave, sattā sadevakā lokā samārakā sabrahmakā sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya nissaṭā visaññuttā vippamuttā vimariyādīkatena cetasā viharantī”ti.
